question: Question_01_(d)
statement:
Find the value of \emph{k} that makes the following antidifferentiation
formula true:

$\displaystyle \int\frac{7}{5-2x}\,dx = k\ln|5-2x| + C$

where \emph{C} is a constant.
sols:
We proceed as in the hints. Let $\displaystyle u = 5-2x$ so
$\displaystyle du = -2dx$. Substituting gives

\begin{align*}
\int\frac{7}{u} \left(\frac{\,du}{-2}\right) &= -\frac{7}{2} \int \frac{du}{u} \\
&= -\frac72 \ln|u|  +C \\
&= -\frac{7}{2}\ln|5-2x|  +C \\
&= k\ln|5-2x| + C
\end{align*}

Thus, $\displaystyle k = -\frac{7}{2}$
hints:
We can always just try integrating the function on the left. What
technique will work best?
